title: Christian mum’s rant about ‘filthy’ potty training book makes it a bestseller
text:
Simon Harris received a complaint after a Christian mum looked up ‘fudgie’ on Urban Dictionary (Picture: Kennedy News and Media)

The author of a potty training book was blasted by a Christian mum for ‘brainwashing kids with filth’, only to soar to the top of Amazon’s best seller list.

Award-winning dad blogger Simon Harris was stunned when he received the furious complaint on Sunday from a reader called Marjorie, who bought a copy of ‘Little Budgie’s Done A Fudgie’.

She said the writer ‘should be ashamed of himself’ and demanded a refund from Amazon after learning ‘fudgie’ referred to a sex act.

But Simon says is is simply another word for ‘poo’ that made his autistic son Luke Harris, now five, laugh when tackling potty training in 2017.

He says he ‘couldn’t give a rat’s ass’ about her grievance because it’s clearly given his sales a massive boost.

In her complaint, Marjorie said she bought the book for her Kindle and noticed her older teenage son ‘giggling hysterically’ as she read it to her little girl.

Emma Harris, three, poses with her dad’s bestselling book (Picture: Kennedy News and Media) She said: ‘I asked him what was so funny and he told me what ‘fudgie’ really means. It’s disgusting and you should be shamed of yourself.

‘I Googled it afterwards and on Urban Dictionary and have attached a screenshot.

‘It’s hard enough to raise good Christian children in the USA in 2019 and keep them away from this filth without people like you subconsciously brainwashing them.

‘Why would [you] use a word that implies fellatio after sodomy?’

Simon used the message as an opportunity to advertise his £4.99 book by sharing it on his Facebook page Men Behaving Dadly.

Thousands of people clicked through to the Amazon listing and his work is now sitting as the site’s number one best selling children’s book on potty training.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Simon, from Southend-on-sea, Essex, told Marjorie the sexual definition of ‘fudgie’ was not what he meant.

Simon was told he ‘should be ashamed of himself’, but he ‘couldn’t give a rat’s ass’ (Picture: Kennedy News and Media) ‘I’m very passionate about vaccinations and autism awareness and I’m used to getting abuse and dealing with vitriol and bile online – it’s an occupational hazard.

‘I’m a massive believer in taking nasty experiences and turning it into something positive, when I read the angry message I just laughed at it.’

‘Marjorie is from the US, possibly from the Bible Belt, and was angry because she was convinced that “fudgie” was referring to a disgusting sex act, which it isn’t.

‘People are now actually buying it off the back of her comment, it’s a nice feeling to know the book is now an Amazon bestseller.’

Simon, who is also dad to Emma, three, and 19-month-old James, came up with the idea for the book to help his son Luke master the potty.

He decided to share Marjorie’s complaint as a way to promote his new book (Picture: Kennedy News and Media) Children on the autistic spectrum commonly have difficulties and take longer training to use one.

Simon said: ‘We went to a supermarket and were looking at potty training books but I couldn’t see any with an animal.

‘I was spitballing all these potential words for poo and was thinking of rhymes like “dog on the bog” but when I said “little budgie and a fudgie” he laughed a lot so I turned it into a poem, which he really loved.’

Advertisement

He then went on to turn it into a book in January last year and he, along with music teacher wife Rachael Harris, 34, also taught daughter Emma with it.

Marjorie’s complaint was prompted after the proud dad shared a picture of Emma holding the book with a beaming smile on her face on Sunday afternoon.

His release ended up soaring to the top of the bestseller list for children’s potty training books (Picture: Amazon) Simon said: ‘The bit about it being “hard to raise good Christian children” made me laugh.

‘I’m not against any religion, but how on earth has your teenager heard of this word?’

Messaging Marjorie back, he said: ‘I shared your concerns with my Facebook audience, and my book ended up going to the top of the Amazon bestseller chart overnight.

‘Therefore, to use a phrase that is popular on your side of The Atlantic, I could not give “a rat’s ass”.’

Amazon has been contacted for comment.

description: Simon Harris' potty training book "little budgie and a fudgie" is now an Amazon bestseller thanks to a complaint from a Christian mum.
